Where Things Go Wrong

Your sessions frequently end before meaningful work is completed, with Claude spending too much time planning and exploring rather than executing changes.

Premature Session Endings with Incomplete Work
A significant number of your sessions end before Claude finishes implementing anything, leaving you with exploration and plans but no actual code changes. Consider giving Claude more runway to complete tasks, or break requests into smaller, immediately actionable pieces rather than open-ended ones.
  • You asked Claude to confirm button behavior and add a success toast, but the session ended after Claude only began reading the code — resulting in zero progress toward the actual goal.
  • You asked Claude to restrict public agent visibility, but Claude was still in the planning/exploration phase when you interrupted, meaning no implementation was delivered.
Excessive Verbosity and Over-Planning Instead of Action
Claude frequently over-elaborates with lengthy plans and multiple planning iterations when you need concise, direct answers or immediate implementation. You can mitigate this by explicitly requesting brevity upfront or instructing Claude to skip planning and go straight to implementation.
  • You asked about a PostHog funnel approach and Claude produced verbose plans with multiple plan-mode exits, forcing you to interrupt and explicitly ask for a concise answer — wasting time you could have spent on implementation.
  • Claude spent an entire session exploring code and writing a detailed plan for a fix rather than making actual changes, and you had to interrupt before any edits were made.
Environment and Data Blind Spots Causing Failures
Claude sometimes hits walls with environment-specific issues — commands that don't work in your setup or missing dev data — without quickly recognizing the problem and pivoting. You could help by providing environment constraints upfront or adding custom instructions about your toolchain and dev data state.
  • Claude tried multiple command variations for 'cn check' (TUI mode, then 'cn review') but none worked in your environment, burning the entire session without completing the task.
  • After successfully implementing acceptance rate metric changes, the UI showed no data because the dev database lacked populated suggestionStatus values, requiring an unexpected backfill that wasn't anticipated during planning.

Custom Skills
Reusable prompts that run with a single /command for repetitive workflows.
Why for you: Git operations and merge conflict resolution are your #1 goals (41 sessions each). A /merge skill would eliminate repeated instructions and ensure Claude acts immediately instead of over-planning.
mkdir -p .claude/skills/merge && cat > .claude/skills/merge/SKILL.md << 'EOF' # Merge Skill 1. Run `git pull origin main` 2. If there are merge conflicts, use Task agents in parallel to resolve each conflicted file 3. After resolving, run `git add .` and verify with `git diff --cached` 4. Do NOT write a plan - just execute immediately EOF
Custom Skills
Create a /check skill for running CI checks locally.
Why for you: You had an entire failed session trying to run `cn check`. A skill that encodes the correct command for your repo means Claude never guesses wrong again.
mkdir -p .claude/skills/check && cat > .claude/skills/check/SKILL.md << 'EOF' # Check Skill Run the repo's lint and type checks. Steps: 1. Read package.json to find the correct check/lint scripts 2. Run them via `npm run <script>` or `pnpm <script>` 3. If checks fail, fix the issues and re-run 4. Never guess CLI commands - always verify from package.json first EOF
Hooks
Shell commands that auto-run at specific lifecycle events.
Why for you: With 48K edits across a massive TypeScript codebase, auto-running type checks after edits would catch bugs early instead of discovering them in CI. This addresses the 'buggy_code' friction and failed CI test sessions.
// Add to .claude/settings.json { "hooks": { "postToolUse": [ { "tool": "Edit", "command": "npx tsc --noEmit --pretty 2>&1 | head -20", "description": "Type-check after edits" } ] } }

On the Horizon

Your data reveals a team shipping heavily in TypeScript with strong multi-file edit capabilities, but sessions frequently end before completion or suffer from over-planning — pointing to massive gains from autonomous, test-driven, and parallelized agent workflows.

Autonomous CI Fix-and-Verify Loops
Instead of sessions ending before fixes are applied, Claude can autonomously run failing CI checks, implement fixes, re-run the test suite, and iterate until green — all without human intervention. With 7 debugging sessions and recurring CI failures in your data, this pattern alone could recover dozens of hours per month and eliminate the 'session ended before fix was applied' antipattern.
Getting started: Use Claude Code's headless mode or the Task tool to spawn a sub-agent that runs tests in a loop. Pair with a CLAUDE.md instruction like 'Always run the full test suite after making changes and iterate until all tests pass.'
Paste into Claude Code:
Find and fix all failing CI tests in this repo. For each failure: 1) Run the test suite with `npm test` or the appropriate command, 2) Read the failing test and the source code it exercises, 3) Identify the root cause, 4) Implement the minimal fix, 5) Re-run the specific failing test to confirm it passes, 6) Re-run the full suite to check for regressions. Repeat until all tests are green. Do NOT stop at a plan — make the actual code changes and verify them.
Parallel Agents for Merge Conflicts
With 41 merge conflict resolution sessions already in your data and a proven case of resolving conflicts across 9 files with parallel agents, you can fully automate branch maintenance. Spawn parallel Task agents — one per conflicted file — that each understand the intent of both branches, resolve semantically (not just textually), and run relevant tests to validate their resolution.
Getting started: Use the Task tool to fan out conflict resolution across files in parallel. Add a CLAUDE.md rule: 'When resolving merge conflicts, use Task sub-agents for each file and always run tests after resolution before committing.'
Paste into Claude Code:
Pull the latest main branch and resolve all merge conflicts in this PR branch. For each conflicted file, spawn a parallel sub-agent using the Task tool that: 1) Reads both versions of the conflicted code, 2) Understands the intent of each change by reading surrounding context and recent commit messages, 3) Resolves the conflict preserving both intents, 4) Validates the resolution compiles. After all files are resolved, run the full test suite, fix any regressions, then commit with a message summarizing what was resolved and push.
Screenshot-Driven UI Iteration Against Designs
You already have 2,610 screenshot captures and 1,978 navigation events — your team is visually verifying UI work. Take this further: give Claude a design spec or reference screenshot, have it implement the UI change, take a screenshot via the Chrome DevTools MCP, compare against the spec, and iterate autonomously until the output matches. This eliminates the 40 'ui_styling_fix' sessions that often ended incomplete or with excessive changes.
Getting started: Use the mcp__chrome-devtools__take_screenshot and navigate_page tools in a loop. Provide a reference image or detailed design spec in your prompt and instruct Claude to self-evaluate each iteration.
Paste into Claude Code:
Fix the styling of the [component name] to match the following design spec: [paste spec or describe exact requirements including spacing, colors, typography, and responsive behavior]. After each change: 1) Save the file, 2) Wait for hot reload, 3) Navigate to the relevant page using mcp__chrome-devtools__navigate_page, 4) Take a screenshot using mcp__chrome-devtools__take_screenshot, 5) Compare the screenshot against the spec and identify remaining discrepancies, 6) Make corrections and repeat until the implementation matches exactly. Do not over-engineer — make minimal targeted CSS/component changes. Show me the final screenshot when done.
